repnme.cdata!:
Zambia - First, Second, and Third Poverty
            Reduction Support Credits Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the First, Second, and Third
            Poverty Reduction Support Credits Project (PRSC) for Zambia
            were as follows: outcomes were moderately satisfactory, the
            risk to development outcome was moderate, the Bank
            performance was moderately satisfactory, and the Borrower
            performance was also moderately satisfactory. Some lessons
            learned included: success was more noticeable in areas which
            coincided with Government's own priorities and where
            Bank had other instruments to engage outside the Poverty
            Reduction Budget Support (PRBS) framework. This is quite
            evident in the declining overall performance of the
            Government on Performance Assessment Framework (PAF)
            indicators in the past few years. There are several reasons
            behind this conclusion. One, the PAF document itself is the
            outcome of protracted negotiations and compromises between
            different groups of donors and the Government. As such it
            reflects the minimum common denominator as to what can be
            achieved and is unlikely to be a true reflection of
            Government's most strongly held priorities. Two, the
            context of budget support in Zambia has changed; ODA has
            declined dramatically as a share of Government's
            resources and unless the PAF mimics Government's
            strongly held priorities, it will have limited impact. The
            Bank should manage transitions within the Bank team more
            systematically. This is indeed a very general point but in
            this particular case it became very important. The
            Bank's absence from key PAF revision discussions due to
            staff transition had significant implications for the PRSC.
            It led to a misalignment between PAF and PRSC and strained
            relations between the Bank, donors and government.

17924227.majtheme: Public sector governance,Economic management,Financial and private sector development

repnme.cdata!:
Zambia - Third Poverty Reduction Support
            Credit Project : summary of discussion

abstracts.cdata!:
The Executive Directors approved the
            Third Poverty Reduction Support Credit Project to the
            Republic of Zambia in the amount of SDR 19.3 million (US$30
            million equivalent) on the payment terms and conditions set
            out in the President's Memorandum. Directors supported
            the operation and its alignment with the priorities set
            forth in the country assistance strategy. Directors welcomed
            the authorities' commitment to maintain macroeconomic
            stability and encouraged continued reforms to advance the
            Government's strategy to promote more sustainable and
            inclusive growth in Zambia, including in the area of public
            financial management. Finally, Directors highlighted the
            importance of effective donor collaboration and alignment,
            and urged close coordination among the cooperating partners
            to ensure effective implementation.

repnme.cdata!:
Zambia - Third Poverty Reduction Support
            Credit Program

abstracts.cdata!:
The Third Poverty Reduction Support
            Credit Program (PRSC-3) is the last in a programmatic series
            of annual poverty reduction support credits to the country.
            PRSC-1 (US$20 million equivalent) was approved in March 2010
            and PRSC-2 (US$30 million equivalent) in February 2011. The
            PRSC credits provide support to a policy and institutional
            reform program emanating from government's development
            strategy articulated in the Fifth National Development Plan
            (FNDP) for the period 2006-2010 and other strategic
            documents and reform programs prepared by the government.
            The successor to the FNDP, the Sixth National Development
            Plan (SNDP) for the period 2011-2015, was prepared by the
            outgoing government and adopted in February 2011. The PRSC
            program is in good alignment with SNDP as well. Policy
            preferences of the new Patriotic Front (PF) government that
            assumed office in September 2011 display commitment to the
            reform activities monitored by the PRSC series. This was
            evidenced in the team's policy discussions with the
            government and progress being made on the activities. The
            Country Assistance Strategy (CAS) identified budget support
            as the primary instrument towards implementing Bank's
            macroeconomic program over the period 2008-11. It provided a
            resource envelope of 15-20 percent of the International
            Development Association (IDA) country allocation for budget
            support. The objectives of the Bank's macroeconomic
            program identified in the CAS are to help Zambia in better
            management of its financial resources, in improving
            accountability and transparency in the use of financial
            resources, and in implementing its reform programs to
            improve public sector efficiency and business environment.
            The PRSC process also provides a forum for broader policy
            dialogue with the government and other major stakeholders.
